author: Laura Curtis, Ruth Liao
description: The Trump administration scrapped penalties for US liquefied natural gas companies that were set to take effect next week under a sweeping policy aimed at curbing China’s maritime dominance.
title: US Ends LNG Ship Penalty, Sets Tariffs in Escalating Feud With China

author: Lauren Dezenski, Jennifer A Dlouhy
description: President Donald Trump announced his plans to travel to Cairo and Jerusalem to herald an agreement that has halted the fighting in Gaza and set the stage for Hamas to release hostages the militant group is holding.
title: Trump Announces Visit to Cairo and Jerusalem to Mark Peace Deal

author: Erik Larson
description: On Oct. 9, the US Justice Department issued an indictment against New York Attorney General Letitia James, alleging bank fraud and false statements to a financial institution related to a mortgage on a Virginia property. The filing came after President Donald Trump publicly urged prosecutors to bring criminal charges against James, who won a contentious civil fraud trial against Trump and his family company in 2024.
title: The Mortgage Fraud Charges Against Letitia James, Explained

author: Patricia Laya, Andreina Itriago
description: President Nicolás Maduro has described opposition leader María Corina Machado as a “wild demoness,” a “war criminal,” and “la Sayona,” a vengeful spirit from Venezuelan folklore.
title: Nobel Winner Vilified by Maduro Regime Vows to Keep Up Her Fight in Venezuela

author: Dasha Afanasieva, Debby Wu, Maggie Eastland
description: Businesses across the global semiconductor supply chain are bracing themselves for disruptions from China’s most targeted move yet to limit their supplies of rare-earth materials, which are critical to building the chips fueling the artificial intelligence boom.
title: The World’s Chip Supply Chain Is Bracing for Fallout From China’s Rare-Earth Curbs

author: Joe Sobczyk
description: This is Washington Edition, the newsletter about money, power and politics in the nation’s capital. Today, senior editor Joe Sobczyk looks at the president’s threat of new tariffs on China. Sign up here. Email our editors here.
title: Trump Returns China Trade Tensions to the Front Burner

author: Janet Lorin
description: The Massachusetts Institute of Technology’s endowment returned 14.8%, its best performance in three years, but warned the school faces financial uncertainty from increased taxes and headwinds from government policies geared towards higher education.
title: MIT Scores 15% Gain to Boost Fund to $27 Billion, Warns of Taxes

author: Samy Adghirni, William Horobin
description: President Emmanuel Macron reappointed Sebastien Lecornu to be France’s prime minister, giving the centrist ally another shot at naming a new cabinet and getting a budget through a fractious parliament.
title: Macron Reappoints Sebastien Lecornu as France’s Prime Minister

author: Courtney McBride, Anthony Capaccio
description: The Pentagon announced plans to build a facility to house Qatari F-15 fighter jets and train its pilots at Mountain Home Air Force Base in Idaho, further deepening a partnership with a US ally that has played a key role in President Donald Trump’s efforts to broker a Gaza peace agreement.
title: US to Host Qatar Planes, Pilots for Joint Training at Idaho Base

author: Alicia Clanton
description: California Governor Gavin Newsom signed a bill aimed at ramping up the housing supply, bucking opposition from detractors including Los Angeles Mayor Karen Bass and neighborhoods around the state’s largest city.
title: Gavin Newsom Stares Down LA Revolt in California Housing Fight

author: Marcelo Rochabrun
description: Investors are betting that Peru’s top-performing economy will emerge unscathed by the latest bout of political chaos to hit the nation.
title: Investors See Peru’s Star Economy Unscathed by Political Chaos

author: Patrick Van Oosterom
description: Dutch far-right lawmaker Geert Wilders temporarily suspended his election campaign after local authorities informed him he was a potential target of a terrorist plot that was disrupted by Belgian authorities.
title: Dutch Far-Right Leader Suspends Campaign After Terrorist Plot

author: Shruti Singh
description: The Chicago Board of Education tapped $200 million from its short-term revolving credit agreement with PNC Bank.
title: Strapped Chicago Schools Taps $200 Million From Credit Line

author: Zoe Tillman
description: Unions representing hundreds of thousands of federal workers have asked a judge to immediately halt mass layoffs that the White House announced on Friday amid the government shutdown.
title: Federal Worker Unions Seek Immediate Halt to Shutdown Layoffs

author: Alexandra Semenova, Natalia Kniazhevich
description: President Donald Trump’s trade war is far from over.
title: Trump Threats Roil Stock Bulls ‘Complacent’ About Trade War

author: Patrick Van Oosterom
description: The Netherlands has allocated €200 million ($232 million) to strengthen Ukraine’s anti—drone capabilities, according to Dutch Defense Minister Ruben Brekelmans.
title: Dutch Pledge €200 Million to Bolster Ukraine’s Anti-Drone System

author: Piotr Skolimowski
description: Russia has intensified its air strikes on Ukrainian cities as part of a deliberate strategy to cripple the country’s energy system and demoralize its population after a summer offensive failed to gain traction.
title: Russia Ramps Up Strikes on Ukraine Energy After Offensive Stalls

author: Andrea Dudik
description: Czech billionaire Andrej Babis reached an agreement with two smaller parties on the distribution of ministries in a new cabinet as he seeks to forge a new ruling majority.
title: Czech Election Winner Babis Agrees With Parties on Cabinet Posts

author: Rachel Cohrs Zhang, Madison Muller, Ashleigh Furlong
description: AstraZeneca Plc is expected to announce a deal with President Donald Trump to slash drug prices, people familiar with the plans said, making it the second pharmaceutical company to strike an agreement to advance one of the administration’s key health priorities.
title: AstraZeneca Is Said to Reach Drug-Price Deal With Trump

author: Lauren Dezenski
description: First lady Melania Trump said she had established a line of communication with Russian President Vladimir Putin, and that the discussions had resulted in eight Ukrainian children being reunited with their families.
title: Melania Trump Says Putin Talks Resulted in Eight Ukrainian Kids Returned

author: Gregory Korte
description: President Donald Trump’s Budget Director Russell Vought says the White House is making good on threats to fire federal workers amid a government shutdown now in its 10th day, upping the stakes for his spending impasse with Democrats in Congress.
title: White House Says Federal Worker Layoffs Begin Amid Shutdown

author: Mathieu Dion, Monique Mulima
description: Canada needs to assess US government investments in the country’s critical minerals companies on a “case-by-case basis” at a time when the Trump administration is pursuing a nationalist economic policy, Industry Minister Melanie Joly said.
title: Canada Will Review Trump Minerals Deals Carefully, Minister Says

author: Andreina Itriago, Eric Martin
description: Donald Trump called Venezuelan opposition leader María Corina Machado to congratulate her for her Nobel Peace Prize, according to people familiar with the matter, despite speculation that he would be indignant at not receiving the award himself.
title: Machado Congratulated by Trump, Dedicates Nobel Partly to Him

author: Molly Smith
description: The Bureau of Labor Statistics said it will publish the September consumer price index on Oct. 24, marking a rare exception to release data during the government shutdown.
title: BLS to Publish September CPI Report on Oct. 24 Despite Shutdown

author: Srinivasan Sivabalan
description: Markets rallied around the Middle East this week with progress on a Gaza ceasefire deal sending Israeli and Egyptian stocks to record highs and boosting a rebound in Saudi Arabia.
title: Rising Mideast Markets Have Traders Wary of Chasing More Gains

author: Jorge Valero, Alberto Nardelli
description: The European Union will work with the US on a fresh plan to enact the next phase of their trade deal, aiming to sideline Washington’s proposal that the bloc unwind regulations President Donald Trump has long derided, according to people familiar with the matter.
title: EU Plans New Proposal With US to Implement Trade Deal

author: William Horobin
description: French President Emmanuel Macron told political groups at a crisis meeting on Friday that he will name a new prime minister in the coming hours rather than calling snap elections, according to a lawmaker who participated in the talks.
title: Macron Said He Will Name Premier in Coming Hours: Lawmaker

author: Yoshiaki Nohara, Sakura Murakami
description: Japan’s political landscape has entered uncharted territory. The ruling Liberal Democratic Party has lost its coalition partner, Komeito, ending a 26-year alliance that had helped anchor Japan’s government and ensured stability for much of the past quarter century.
title: What the Collapse of the Ruling Coalition Means for Japan

author: Janet Lorin, Liam Knox
description: The Massachusetts Institute of Technology rejected the Trump administration’s latest effort to reorient higher education toward its policy priorities, spurning a proposal that calls for universities to accept a series of demands in exchange for preferential access to federal funding.
title: MIT Rejects Trump’s Rowan-Backed University Funding Compact

author: William Standring
description: Travelers entering Europe face new digital controls this weekend that risk leading to increased delays at the border.
title: Travelers Face Border-Delay Risk as EU Controls Start Sunday

author: Will Wade, Ari Natter
description: The US is canceling a huge solar project in Nevada, the latest effort by President Donald Trump to limit renewable energy development.
title: US Cancels Major Solar Project in Nevada Biden Had Championed

author: Ruth Olurounbi
description: Nigeria is considering adopting a law aimed at increasing female representation in its legislatures, currently the lowest in Africa on a proportionate basis.
title: Nigeria Weighs New Law to Boost Gender Parity in Legislatures

author: Emily Birnbaum, Erik Wasson
description: Liberal groups are throwing their money and followers into fortifying Democratic resolve in the lengthening shutdown fight, bolstering vulnerable incumbents who stand firm and preparing to pounce on any wayward senators who show signs of wavering on health care priorities.
title: Progressive Groups Set to Spend Big to Keep Democrats United on Shutdown

author: Greg Ryan, Ike Swetlitz
description: The newest Republican candidate for Massachusetts governor plans to use the fortune he reaped in part from Johnson & Johnson’s acquisition of his medical-device company to outflank his opponents and defend his tenure at the heart-pump maker.
title: J&J Deal Fuels Ex-Abiomed CEO’s Bid for Massachusetts Governor

author: Laura Dhillon Kane
description: Canadian travel to the US continued its steep decline last month amid President Donald Trump’s trade war and border crackdown.
title: Canadian Road Trips to US Plunge For Ninth Straight Month

author: Gresa Kraja
description: Kosovo’s parliament chose a Serb deputy speaker, potentially ending eight months of political deadlock in the Balkan nation that’s prevented the formation of a government and new institutions.
title: Kosovo Parliament Moves to End Deadlock as Serb List Cries Foul

author: Naureen S Malik
description: When utilities from Pennsylvania, New Jersey and Maryland established what is today the largest US grid, they aimed to provide power at the lowest possible price. But nearly 70 years later, the cost of securing power has surged to record highs, prompting Pennsylvania Governor Josh Shapiro to threaten to leave the now-13-state network.
title: Pennsylvania Wants to Leave the Biggest US Grid. It Won’t be Easy.

author: Ram Anand, Eduard Gismatullin
description: Malaysia’s consumption and tourism-related companies are set to get a boost as the government increases cash handouts to cushion the impact of higher cost of living on citizens.
title: Here Are The Winners and Losers of Malaysia’s 2026 Spending Plan

author: Christina Kyriasoglou
description: China’s expansion of export controls to production facilities outside of China is a concern being discussed in Germany and at the EU level, a spokesperson for the German Economic Ministry said in an email.
title: Germany Calls New China Rare Earth Curbs a ‘Great Concern’

author: Andrea Palasciano
description: The North Atlantic Treaty Organization’s annual nuclear deterrence drills will begin on Monday, Secretary General Mark Rutte said — a routine event with added significance as the US mulls scaling down its military presence in Europe.
title: NATO Launches Annual Nuclear Drill as Europe Rethinks Deterrence

author: Anthony Halpin
description: There simply weren’t enough Arab leaders saying ‘yes’ to warrant holding a summit. That’s what forced Russian President Vladimir Putin into a last-minute delay of an event he’d hoped would boost his standing in the region.
title: Putin Scraps Summit on Lack of Attendance From Arab Leaders

author: Philip Aldrick, Joe Mayes
description: Rachel Reeves is coming under pressure to increase the buffer against her fiscal rules at next month’s UK budget, to create what one economist called a “virtuous circle” that quells bond-market uncertainty and ends the need for further tax rises this parliament.
title: Reeves Faces Mounting Calls to Expand UK’s Fiscal Buffer

author: Justin Sink
description: In awarding the Peace Prize to Maria Corina Machado of Venezuela, the Norwegian Nobel Committee recognized “a woman who keeps the flame of democracy burning amid a growing darkness.”
title: World Awaits Blowback as the Nobel Slips From Trump’s Hands

author: Justin Sink
description: Nobel committee decision certain to register as the latest in a lifetime of rejection by elites.
title: World Braces for Trump’s Peace-Prize Snub Backlash

author: Vlad Savov
description: China has begun an investigation into a months-old Qualcomm Inc. acquisition, taking aim at yet another US technology giant before a pivotal meeting of the leaders of the world’s two largest economies.
title: China Opens Antitrust Probe of Qualcomm’s Autotalks Deal

author: Heidi Taksdal Skjeseth, Ott Ummelas
description: Venezuelan opposition leader Maria Corina Machado was awarded the 2025 Nobel Peace Prize for fighting for democracy at a time when political freedom is increasingly at risk from the rise of authoritarian regimes.
title: Nobel Peace Prize Goes to Venezuela Opposition Leader Machado

author: Fares Alghoul, Galit Altstein, Dan Williams
description: Israel’s cabinet approved a deal that will see Hamas free all remaining hostages held in Gaza in exchange for around 2,000 prisoners, a major step toward ending a two-year war that’s killed tens of thousands of people and destabilized the wider Middle East.
title: Israeli Cabinet Backs Deal, Paving Way for Hostages Release

author: Sakura Murakami, Yoshiaki Nohara
description: Japan’s governing coalition abruptly collapsed in a major blow to new ruling party leader Sanae Takaichi, plunging the country into one of its biggest political crises in decades and jolting markets.
title: Japan’s Decades-Old Ruling Coalition Collapses, Jolting Markets

author: Antony Sguazzin, Daryna Krasnolutska
description: The manufacturer says it’s unclear how Russia obtained the equipment because it isn’t supposed to be sold for military use.
title: South Africa Investigates How It Made a Part for Russian Drones

author: Colum Murphy, Josh Xiao
description: Presidents Donald Trump and Xi Jinping are maneuvering for leverage ahead of their upcoming meeting and the expiration of a US-China trade truce, even at the risk of escalating tensions between the world’s two biggest economies.
title: Trump and Xi Maneuver for Leverage as Meeting, Truce Expiry Loom

author: Christopher Jungstedt
description: Sweden plans to strengthen and speed up its buildup of anti-drone capabilities given a spate of recent violations in the region, Minister for Defence Pal Jonson said Friday in a post on X.
title: Sweden Pledges More Money to Bolster Its Anti-Drone Capabilities

author: Marcelo Rochabrun
description: Peruvian President Dina Boluarte, who has one of lowest recorded approval ratings for a world leader, was removed from office Friday after she was ditched by allies in congress who backed a motion to oust her over soaring crime.
title: Peru’s Boluarte Ousted as Ex-Allies Back Impeachment

author: Moses Mozart Dzawu, Pius Lukong
description: Paul Biya, the world’s oldest president, wants to rule Cameroon at least until he’s 99. That has investors worried about strife in the African nation prone to conflict.
title: World’s Oldest Ruler Wants New Cameroon Term, Alarming Investors

author: Daniel Flatley, Manuela Tobias
description: For Scott Bessent’s $20 billion bet on Argentina to pay off, a lot of things have to go right – things that in the past, in Argentina, have tended to go wrong.
title: Bessent’s Big Gamble on Argentina Has a Narrow Road to Pay Off

author: Jasmina Kuzmanovic
description: Slovenia’s top diplomat warned Bosnian Serbs against holding a referendum that could threaten the integrity of Bosnia-Herzegovina and jeopardize the Balkan nation’s chances of eventually joining the European Union.
title: Slovenia Signals Bosnian Serbs Referendum Would Hurt EU Chances

author: Levin Stamm
description: Swiss voters want the government to walk away from a deal to buy three dozen F-35 fighter jets from Lockheed Martin Corp. because of a disagreement over the contract and a risk that the price could increase by as much as 1.3 billion francs ($1.6 billion).
title: Swiss Want to Ditch US Fighter-Jet Deal on Cost Spat, Poll Finds

author: Sakura Murakami
description: Japan’s Sanae Takaichi will meet her ruling coalition counterpart on Friday afternoon, amid fears of a possible rupturing of the 26-year partnership that has been a bedrock for political stability in the nation.
title: Japan’s Ruling Coalition Leaders Meet Amid Fears of Rupture

author: Yian Lee
description: Taiwan will speed up building a comprehensive air defense system to protect the self-run democracy, President Lai Ching-te said — an announcement that comes as the US pushes Taipei to do more to defend itself from China.
title: Taiwan’s Lai Unveils Plan for ‘T-Dome’ Air Defense System

author: Oma Seddiq
description: Advanced artificial intelligence chipmakers Nvidia Corp. and Advanced Micro Devices Inc. would have to ensure US companies get priority access to their products before China under legislation the Senate passed, a setback for the industry’s efforts to block the measure.
title: Senate Passes AI Chip Export Limits on Nvidia, AMD to China

author: Steven T. Dennis
description: The US Senate backed legislation that would bar certain Chinese biotech companies from receiving federal funding and prohibit American investments in sensitive Chinese industries late Thursday night.
title: Senate Targets Chinese Biotech, Investments in Defense Bill

author: Matthew Brockett
description: New Zealand Finance Minister Nicola Willis said she would support any reforms to enhance transparency at the central bank under its new governor.
title: Willis Supports RBNZ Transparency Reforms Under New Governor

author: Olesia Safronova
description: Ukraine’s capital, Kyiv, was hit by a massive drone and missile attack targeting civilian infrastructure and municipal energy facilities, according to local authorities, who blamed Russia for the strikes.
title: Russia Launches Drone and Missile Attack on Kyiv, Local Officials Say

author: Skylar Woodhouse
description: Virginia gubernatorial candidates Abigail Spanberger and Winsome Earle-Sears clashed over a range of issues that included political violence, the ongoing government shutdown and cost-of-living as they faced off in an often-tense debate.
title: Virginia Governor Hopefuls Spar on Economy, Violent Texts
